newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada union ends auto talks by ratifying Ford deal.
newsitem.headline: Canada union ends auto talks by ratifying Ford deal.

text.p: The Canadian Auto Workers union ended the 1996 labor negotiations with the automotive industry after the union's 11,700 members ratified a tentative collective agreement with Ford Motor Co of Canada Ltd.

"The union challenged management's unilateral right to outsource work, set a new standard for corporate conduct and defied the analysts who said it couldn't be done," said CAW president, Buzz Hargrove, in a CAW statement.
The union said 93.7 percent of its Ford membership voted in favor of the deal, the statement said.

The Ford agreement closes off a round of bargaining, considered by many to be anticlimactic in the wake of a 20-day strike at General Motors Corp in Canada and a down-to-the-wire deal at Chrysler Corp's Canadian subsidiary, which set the pattern agreement for 1996.

Traditionally the union sets the pattern at its first negotiating target for a three-year labor deal and then forces the other two North American auto companies to match it by threatening to or holding a strike.
Hargrove told reporters Wednesday that the union's master committee unanimously recommended the deal to its Ford membership and would hold a ratification vote Saturday and Sunday.

The pattern deal offers the union protection from outsourcing, or contracting out jobs, ensures minimum health and safety and employment standards and gives workers improved benefits and a 10.2 percent wage and cost of living increase over three years.
Hargrove said Wednesday that the provisions restricting outsourcing would be a big part of the union's bargaining position for workers it represents in other industries.
The Ford deal includes a ban on the sale or closing of all Ford plants in Canada, except Ford's Windsor, Ontario, engine plant, which is being closed this month.
